history.content: As long as you are taking at least 2 technical courses and 12 units per term and have completed all of your EECS requirements, it doesn't matter if they aren't in EECS. Technical courses are those in engineering, mathematics, chemistry, physics, statistics, biological sciences and computer science. Please be aware that this only applies to EECS majors.  All other majors should consult with their department or ESS Advisor. Source: http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/Programs/Notes/section2.shtml

As long as you are taking at least 2 technical courses and 12 hours per term, it doesn't matter if they aren't in EECS. Technical courses are those in engineering, mathematics, chemistry, physics, statistics, biological sciences and computer science. Source: http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/Programs/Notes/section2.shtml

children.subject: Only the ones that are in the areas listed in Sarah's response. The CS technical elective approval process is separate from whatever CoE does to determine what they consider technical courses.

So if a class in a science department like physics or biology but is crosslisted under a non-technical department (like the L&S department) and we sign up under the non-technical department's listing, would that class be still considered a technical if we take it?

It would be best for you to email your ESS Advisor with specific courses to see whether they would count as technical courses or not.  We do not refer to the Computer Science Technical Elective List in determining technical courses.  As long as your ESS Advisor knows which course you are taking to satisfy which specific requirement s/he can let you know if it will work and make note of it in your file.
Hi, I was wondering.... speaking of technical classes, for EECS majors, does the "CS technicals" in this list apply? http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/csugrad/tech_electives

history.content: I'm an EECS major, and I will have finished all my major requirements in Spring 2015. Fall 2015, I want to take a 16 unit schedule with 3 technical classes on a letter grade basis; however, all of these technical classes would be IEOR classes, as I am trying to complete an IEOR minor. Am I allowed to do this?
history.subject: EECS 2 technical class requirement
